Emissions of carbon dioxide can lead to the greenhouse effect, causing global warming and so on. conversion of carbon dioxide into high-value chemicals through catalysis, which is an effective method to successfully curb carbon emissions and prevent the greenhouse effect. Among them, CO2 chemical synthesis of cyclic carbonate is one of the important way. In this paper, a new type of supported ionic liquid catalyst (GO-[DBU][Br]) was synthesized by one-pot method. Subsequently, the GO-[DBU][Br] was applied to the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 in batch reaction and fixed bed continuous reaction, respectively. The stability of the catalyst was also explored, the GO-[DBU][Br] was easily separated and reused at least 5 times without significant loss of catalytic activity. The excellent catalytic performance comes from the synergistic effect of ionic liquid cations, halogenated anions, and a large number of oxygen-containing functional groups on the GO surface, a possible reaction mechanism was thus proposed. The study provides a safe, efficient, and industrial-scale continuous reaction system for CO2 utilization. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Molecular Catalysis Keywords CO2 chemical fixation Cyclic carbonate Supported ionic liquids Graphene oxide Fixed-bed reactor Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. Chemical abbreviations Abbreviations CO2 Carbon dioxide PO Propylene oxide PC Propylene carbonate GO Graphene oxide DBU 1,8-Diazabicyclo [5.4.0] undec-7-ene DMF N,N-Dimethylformamide GO-[DBU][Br] Br anion with DBU cationic supported GO FT-IR Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy XRD Diffraction of x-rays 1 Introduction The emission of carbon dioxide will lead to the greenhouse effect, causing global warming and ocean acidification [1,2]. To cope with this problem, carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies are widely adopted in industry [3,4]. The technology is mainly divided into three stages, namely, CO2 separation from the factory or simple carbon capture, transporting captured CO2 and CO2 sequestration. Recently, it was found that CO2 as a cheap, rich, non-toxic and harmless renewable resource, which can be used as a chemical raw material for the production of methanol, [5] formic acid, [6] urea, [7] fine chemicals [8]. This chemical conversion pathway is called carbon dioxide conversion and utilization (CCU) technologies, has attracted widespread attention [9]. The cycloaddition reaction of CO2 to generate cyclic carbonate (Fig. 1 ), which has broad application prospects [10]. Cyclic carbonate as a product of the reaction is a colorless, odorless liquid widely used as a polar aprotic solvent, electrolyte in lithium-ion batteries, and precursor for the synthesis of polycarbonate and polyurethane [11]. In recent decades, a large number of researchers have developed many specific catalysts, which can be mainly divided into homogeneous catalysts and heterogeneous catalysts according to phase classification. Homogeneous catalysts mainly include: organic bases, [12,13] metal halides, [14] metal complexes,[15] porphyrins, [16] ionic liquids [17]. And heterogeneous catalysts mainly include: nitrogen-doped porous carbon materials,[18] metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), [19] covalent organic frameworks (COFs), [20] polymers, [21] and supported ionic liquids (SILs), [22] etc. Compared with homogeneous catalyst, although heterogeneous catalyst can solve the separation and recovery problems, it still has some disadvantages, such as unsatisfactory catalytic activity, harsh reaction conditions, sensitivity to water, poor lifetime of catalyst, etc. Therefore, it is desirable to prepare heterogeneous catalysts that are nontoxic, efficient, inexpensive, easy to separate, and reusable. Ionic liquids (ILs) are salts that consist entirely of ions and are liquid at a temperature near room temperature [23,24]. It is widely used in the fields of chemistry, electrochemistry, industry, energy and catalysis [25]. Common ionic liquids that can be used for catalysis include: quaternary ammonium salt, quaternary phosphonium salt, imidazolium, pyridine ionic liquid and some alkaloids [26]. Due to the designability of ILs, [27,28] anions and cations can be selected or designed according to actual needs to achieve green and efficient catalytic effects. Graphene Oxide (GO) contains basic components of sp2-hybrid carbon atoms and is rich in oxygen-containing functional groups (e.g., hydroxyl, carbonyl and carboxyl) (Fig. 2 ) [29–32]. Oxygen-containing groups can widen the interlayer gap of GO, making the material easy to modify [33]. Meanwhile, GO, with its metal-free, water-resistant and high specific surface area, is considered a promising CO2 adsorbent and an effective catalyst for CO2 conversion [34,35]. Synergistic effects between hydrogen bond donors (such as hydroxyl and carboxyl groups) and nucleophilic anions were also found, which enhanced the catalytic activity [36–39]. Supported ionic liquids (SILs) are proposed because of many defects of ionic liquids themselves, such as high viscosity, high price, difficult to separate, environmental pollution and easy water absorption [40]. The preparation principle is to immobilize ionic liquid in the pores or lamellar of some nanomaterial carriers, so as to obtain a new material with the characteristics of both ionic liquid and carrier. This new catalyst has successfully solved the problems of separation, recovery and waste of ionic liquid, while still retaining the catalytic performance of ionic liquid. In addition, a large number of epoxy functional groups and hydrogen bonds contained in the carrier pores or lamellae can greatly enhance the adsorption and activation of CO2, in line with the concept of “green chemistry” and “atomic economy” [39]. In this paper, GO was prepared by “improved” Hummers method, and GO-[DBU][Br] was obtained by chemical grafting: first, DBU reacts with (3-chlorpropyl) trimethoxylsilane by nucleophilic substitution, then reacted with the inorganic salt containing the halogen anion, finally silanized by GO with silane to successfully prepare GO-[DBU][Br]. Then CO2 cycloaddition experiments were performed on GO-[DBU][Br] by batch and continuous methods, respectively, the batch reaction parameters were investigated: catalyst dosage (50-200 mg), reaction temperature (80-120 °C), reaction pressure (1-4 MPa), reaction time (2-12 h), and continuous reaction parameters: reaction pressure (1-4 MPa), reaction temperature (80-120 °C), liquid flow rate (0.02-0.1 mL/min), reaction time (0-8 h). The GO and GO-[DBU][Br] were characterized by FT-IR, XRD and Raman spectroscopy. And possible reaction mechanism was discusse. 2 Experimental 2.1 Experimental materials and instruments Among the materials used in this experiment, carbon dioxide (99%) was provided from Dalian Junfeng Gas Company, and propylene oxide (99% purity) was provided from Tianjin Damao Chemical Reagent Factory. Ethanol (AR purity) was provided from Tianjin Fuyu Fine Chemical Co., LTD., ethyl acetate, toluene,N, n-dimethylformamide (all AR purity) was provided from Tianjin Kemiou Chemical Reagent Co., LTD., 1,8-Diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene and (3-Chloropropyl) trimethoxysilane (both 99% purity) were purchased from Aladdin Holdings Group Co., Ltd. All of them can be used without further purification. In the instruments used in this experiment, the high pressure reaction kettle and fixed bed reaction device were homemade. 2.2 Preparation of GO GO was prepared by the “improved” Hummers method [41]. 46 mL concentrated sulfuric acid was poured into the beaker and was cooled in an ice water bath. 1 g (200 mesh) natural flake graphite and 1 g NaNO3 were weighed and slowly added into the beaker. After starting ultrasonic for 1 h, add 8 g potassium permanganate slowly, stir moderately for 2 h, and control the reaction temperature not to exceed 20 °C. Next increase the temperature to about 35 °C and continue stirring for 30 min. Then Slowly add 200 mL deionized water and stir at 95 °C for 30 min. At the end of the reaction, a certain amount of deionized water was added to stop the reaction, and an appropriate amount of hydrogen peroxide was added to reduce the excess oxidant. After 15 min, the solution turned bright yellow and was filtered, washed with 5% HCl solution and deionized water until the pH value of the filtrate was 7. Finally, the filter cake was fully dried in a constant temperature drying oven at 50 °C and stored for later use. 2.3 Preparation of GO-[DBU][Br] The preparation process of catalyst (Fig. 3 ) is as follows: 100 mg 1,8-Diazabicyclo [5.4.0] undec-7-ene (DBU), 100 mg NaBr and 131 mg silane coupling agent (3-Chloropropyl) trimethoxysilaneare are added to round-bottom flasks in turn, and an appropriate amount of N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) is added into the flask. Stir continuously in 80 °C constant temperature water bath for 20 h with reflux (Ⅰ), getting a bright yellow liquid. Then 200 mg of the prepared GO was weighed and dissolved in adequate amounts of DMF. Toluene was added and sonicated for 2 h, add it to the bright yellow liquid. Stir continuously in 80 °C constant temperature water bath for 20 h with reflux (Ⅱ). Finally, the resulting liquid is filtered, a large amount of deionized water and ethanol are alternately rinsed. After the filtration was completed, the obtained filter cake was fully dried in a 50 °C constant temperature drying oven for 24 h to obtain GO-[DBU][Br]. 2.4 Procedure for cycloaddition reactions 2.4.1 Batch reaction The batch reaction was carried out in a stainless steel high-pressure reaction kettle. The left and right ends of the kettle were pipelines and inlet and outlet valves. The upper end was sealed with stainless steel threads. The kettle was equipped with a 50mL volume of lining. The required amount of PO was placed in the lining, and different catalyst masses (50-200 mg) were weighed and added to it. After sealing the reaction kettle, the pressure system was turned on, and the reaction pressure (1-4 MPa) was adjusted by controlling the inlet and outlet valves. Oil bath to adjust the reaction temperature (80-120 °C), set the reaction time (0-12 h), and stir moderately. After the reaction is completed, cool down and slowly release the pressure, unsealing, take out the product and centrifugation, store in a static state. 2.4.2 Continuous reaction The experimental setup and process of the fixed bed reaction are shown in Fig. 4 . The fixed bed reactor is a stainless steel tube with an inner diameter of 8 mm, a length of 270 mm and a thickness of 4 mm. Turn on the gas source, connect CO2, purge the pipeline, start the reaction, and control the high-pressure constant-flow pump to adjust the different PO inlet flow rates (0.02-0.1 mL/min). Control the decompression valve to adjust the pressure of the continuous reaction (1-4 MPa), set the temperature of the tube furnace to adjust the reaction temperature (80-120 °C), the reaction time is 8 h, take sample from the collector once every 2h. After the reaction, stop the liquid feeding, close the tube furnace, recover the product, purge the pipeline, close the gas source, disassemble and wash the stainless steel tube, and store it dry. 2.5 Catalyst characterization The catalysts were characterized by fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), X-ray diffractometry (XRD), Raman spectrum. The FT-IR spectra were recorded using a Bruker vector 22 FT-IR spectrophotometer at a setting of wave number: 500-4000 cm−1 (KBr tablets). The crystal phase was analyzed by XRD with CuKa radiation at a setting of step size: 0.02, angle range: 5-80°, scanning speed: 0.14 °/min. The Raman spectrum studies were performed over an invia Qontor spectrometer at a setting of raman shift: 1000-1800 cm−1. The product was quantified by gas chromatography (GC model: Agilent 6890N), using a (5%-phenyl)-methyl polysiloxane (HP-5) weakly polar capillary column and equipped with an FID detector. The sample was diluted 10 times with ethyl acetate and then measured. The GC conditions consist of automatic injection solution volume of 1 μL, the split ratio of 10:1, vaporizer temperature of 320°C, detector temperature of 320°C, the oven program of 120°C for 1 min, and the temperature rise to 220°C through 15°C/min rate and keep it for 5 min. 2.6 Calculate indicators In order to quantitatively investigate the characteristics and catalytic capacity of the prepared catalyst, the parameters are defined as follows: (1) Grafting rate In the loaded ionic liquid, the ratio of the loaded ionic liquid to the mass of the carrier after loading is defined as the load, namely: (2.1) Grafting rate = Mass of ionic liquid grafted Total mass of supported ionic liquid catalyst × 100 % (1) Conversion rate, yield, selectivity (2.2) Convertio n P O = m P O 1 / M P O − m P O 2 / M P O m P O 1 / M P O × 100 % (2.3) Selectivity = m P C / M P C m P O 1 / M P O − m P O 2 / M P O × 100 % (2.4) Yield = Convertion × Selectivity m PC is the quality of the product propylene carbonate, g; MPC is the mole mass of propylene carbonate, g/mol; m PO1 is the weight of propylene oxide in the raw material, g; m PO2 is the weight of propylene oxide after the reaction, g; MPO is the mole mass of propylene oxide, g/mol. 3 Results and characterization 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 FT-IR FT-IR spectrum characterization was performed on GO, GO-[DBU][Br] and GO-[DBU][Br] was repeated use for 5 times. The results are shown in Fig. 5 . For GO-[DBU][Br] sample, The characteristic peak at 3367 cm−1 were attributed to O-H group on the GO surface [42]. The characteristic peaks at 2927 cm−1 and 2864 cm−1 were attributed to aliphatic C-H stretching vibration;[43] the characteristic peaks at 914 cm−1 and 692 cm−1 were due to the stretching vibration of silane, corresponding to Si-OH and Si-O-C, respectively;[43] and the characteristic peaks at 1525 cm−1, 1325 cm−1 and 1195cm−1 were attributed to stretching vibration of C-N [44]. Compared with GO, the intensity of the absorption peak at 3367 cm−1 is weakened, indicating that the free hydroxyl group on the surface of GO-[DBU][Br] is reduced, the decrease of surface hydroxyl group and the appearance of Si-O-C indicated the silanization of O-H on GO surface with silane. This confirms that the DBU is successfully anchored to the GO surface. In addition, the (c) is the FT-IR detection of GO-[DBU][Br] after repeated five times of intermittent reaction. Compared with the whole new catalyst, all the absorption peaks still exist, indicating that the activity of the catalyst is not lost, but the intensity of the absorption peak is reduced, indicating that part of the ionic liquid grafted on the catalyst is lost after repeated use for five times. 3.1.2 Raman spectroscopy Raman spectroscopy is a characterization method widely used to evaluate the disorder of carbon-based materials [45]. D band and G band are the Raman characteristic peaks of C atom crystal. D band represents the defect of C atom lattice, G band represents the in-plane stretching vibration of C atom sp2 hybridization, and ID/IG is the intensity ratio of D-peak and G-peak. As we said, the D peak represents the defects in the lattice, so the higher the ratio, the more defects in the C crystal. The two main peaks of GO and GO-[DBU][Br] appear around 1320 cm−1 and 1578 cm−1, associated with bands D and G, respectively. The intensity ratio of D band and G band (ID/IG) in GO-[DBU][Br] (0.95) increases compared with that in GO (0.90), indicating that the disorder of graphene lattice increases after GO functionalization (Fig. 6 ). Raman results further confirmed the successful synthesis of GO-[DBU][Br]. 3.1.3 XRD diffraction pattern It was shown the typical diffraction peak (001) of GO curve at 8.4° in Fig. 7 , indicates that the crystal structure of GO is well preserved [46]. Subsequently, by comparing the XRD diffraction patterns of the original GO and GO-[DBU][Br], the intensity of the diffraction peak of GO-[DBU][Br] was greatly reduced, and there were indications that the diffraction peaks become weakened or even disappear when the regular stacks of GO are exfoliated [47]. Therefore, after hydroxyl silanization on GO surface, the lamellar aggregation decreases and the material changes from crystalline to amorphous, which corresponds to the phenomenon of reduced diffraction peak intensity. This phenomenon demonstrates the successful interaction between silane and hydroxyl groups on the GO. 3.1.4 Thermogravimetry analysis TGA was used to evaluate the thermal stability of a solid material and estimate the content of grafted-IL on the support. TGA profiles of GO and GO-[DBU][Br] are presented in Fig. 8 . For GO, the initial weight loss below 110 °C was about 13.3 wt% owing to the removal of adsorbed water. In contrast, GO-[DBU][Br] showed higher thermal stability than GO, which afforded only 6.17% of weightloss atthe temperature range [48]. The weight loss of 170-205 °C is caused by partial [DBU][Br] decomposition. Subsequently, the TG curve at 205-412 °C is also attributed to the decomposition of [DBU][Br], but it is different from the previous curve, which is due to the increase of support stability caused by GO silylation, the weight loss of 34.25% at 170-412 °C corresponds to the grafting rate of catalyst [49]. The above results revealed that GO-[DBU][Br] could endure about 170 °C, much higher than the reaction temperature (120 °C) in following catalytic experiments. 3.2 Investigation of batch reaction parameters The reaction conditions were optimized using GO-[DBU][Br] as raw material. It was described the relationship between yield and catalyst loading at 120 °C, 2 MPa, 3 g PO and 12 h in Fig. 9 a. In the process of increasing from 50 mg to 100 mg, The PC yield increased from 80.9% to 98.1%, and then showed a stable trend. When the amount of catalyst was 200 mg, the PC yield reached 98.2%, which was only increased by 0.1%. Therefore, the appropriate catalyst dosage can be selected on the consideration of the yield and cost. It was described the relationship between PC yield and temperature under 2 MPa, 3 g PO, 100 mg catalyst dosage and reaction time of 12 h in Fig. 9b. At 80 °C, the yield has reached 91.5%, the yield increases from 91.5% to 98.1% with the temperature rise from 80 °C to 120 °C, PO almost all converted into PC, and with the reaction, the selectivity of PC has been maintained at more than 97%, the increase of temperature does not promote the occurrence of negative reactions. The higher the temperature, the more intense the collision between the reactant molecules and the catalyst, that is conducive to increasing the reaction rate, improving the PO conversion rate. The relationship between PC yield and time at different temperatures is shown in the Fig. 9c. The fixed reaction conditions were 2 MPa, 100 mg catalyst, and 3 g PO. Analyzing the 80 °C and 100 °C curves at first, the production rate of PC increased first and then tended to be flat. When the reaction time reached 12 h, the maximum yield reached 88.5% and 97.1%, respectively. For the reaction results at 120 °C, conducted a more detailed study, and the results are shown in Fig. 9d. When the reaction time was from 0.5 h to 1 h, the PC yield rapidly increased from 59% to 89.6%. the PC yield showed a slow increasing trend from 1 h to 12 h, when the reaction time was 12 h, the yield reached 98.1%. It was found that the catalytic effect is significantly enhanced, the rate of catalysis is greatly increased. Therefore, it was verified again that the higher the temperature, the more conducive to the conversion of PO under the premise of ensuring the stability of the catalyst. At the same time, it is also crucial to choose the appropriate reaction time to ensure the full progress of the reaction. The influence of reaction pressure on PC yield is shown in Fig. 9e. The fixed reaction conditions are 120 °C reaction temperature, 100 mg GO-[DBU][Br], 3 g PO, and 12 h reaction time. Combined with the curve, the PC yield showed a trend of first increasing and then decreasing. When the pressure is 2 MPa, the PC yield is the highest, 98.1%. Experimental results show that 2 MPa is the optimum reaction pressure for GO-[DBU][Br]. 3.3 Catalyst stability The stability test for GO-[DBU][Br]. The conditions it was selected were reaction temperature 100 °C, reaction pressure 2 MPa, reaction time 6 h, the initial amount of PO was 6 g and the initial amount of catalyst was 200 mg. The same batch of catalyst was used to repeat the reaction for five times, the PC yield of the five consecutive reactions was 97.1%, 96.5%, 93.1%, 91.8% and 89.4%, respectively. The results were shown in the Fig. 10 . The first reaction only decreased by 7.7% compared with the fifth reaction, the catalyst activity decreased slightly, and the selectivity did not decrease. Combined with FT-IR characterization results, all absorption peaks were still intact, and peak intensity slightly decreased. Therefore, it can be proved that the prepared GO-[DBU][Br] has good stability. The loss of partial activity of the catalyst may be due to the loss of a small amount of ionic liquid. 3.4 Investigation of continuous reaction parameters The excellent performance of the catalyst was confirmed by batch reaction studies. According to the investigation, the fixed bed reactor has a very broad application prospect in industry. Therefore, we applied GO-[DBU][Br] to the fixed-bed reactor to explore its catalytic performance, optimize reaction parameters, and try to find the best process conditions. The fixed-bed reactor used, and PO was selected as the substrate for carbon dioxide cycloaddition reaction. The influence of reaction pressure on reaction yield was studied in Fig. 11 a. According to the bar chart, the PC yield increased first and then decreased with time. At 6 h, the PC yield reached the highest 74.4%. By comparing the reaction results under different pressures, it is confirmed that 2 MPa is the best reaction pressure in the continuous reaction. The phenomenon that PC production first rises and then declines, it is because the PO into the reactor increased slowly, when the PO in the reactor reaches a certain amount and completely reacts with the catalyst, the PC yield can reaches the highest level. The phenomenon that PC production rate decline slightly, the reason is that ionic liquid grafted on the catalyst is slightly lost over time, and the furrow flow may occur in the reactor during the reaction process. Fig. 11b shows the variation trend of PC yield with time at different temperatures (80 °C, 100 °C, 120 °C). Under different time, the PC yield of 80 °C and 100 °C basically did not change greatly, and the yield was low, while under 120 °C, the PC yield increased greatly, and showed a trend of increasing first and then decreasing with time. This also proves that the temperature has a great influence on the catalyst activity under continuous reaction. While the reaction results are quite different under different temperatures, the phenomenon is consistent with the fact that the catalyst activity and catalytic efficiency are greatly improved under 120 °C in batch experiment. Therefore, 120°C is the most favorable temperature for the continuous reaction. Fig. 11c shows the relationship between PC yield and time for three different inlet flow of PO. Before the reaction time was 6 h, the PC production rate was tends to increase over time. At 6 h, the PC yield reached the highest, and after 6 h, the yield began to decline slowly. When the inlet flow of PO was 0.02 mL/min, the PC yield at 6 h was the highest, which was 77.3%. Therefore, 0.02 mL/min is the optimal inlet flow of PO for continuous reaction. 3.5 Catalyst comparison Compared to other reported work (Table 1 ), GO-[DBU][Br] exhibited the advantages of reasonable CO2 pressure and mild temperature for effective CO2 cycloaddition to propylene oxide. The GO-[DBU][Br] catalyst prepared by chemical grafting is easy to separate and recover, and has good catalyst stability. More importantly, The GO-[DBU][Br] is used in fixed-bed reactors to avoid the high temperature and high pressure requirements in the batch reaction process. The reaction process is safe and efficient, with great potential for industrial application, and has guiding significance for the actual production of PC. 4 Possible reaction mechanisms Based on various catalytic systems reported in literature, the synergistic action of halide anions and hydrogen bonds is beneficial to the activation of epoxides, and the alkaline site is beneficial to the adsorption and activation of CO2. Using propylene oxide as the reaction substrate, the catalytic reaction mechanism of cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxide to synthesize cyclocarbonate was proposed (Fig. 12 ). As shown in step Ⅰ, PO coordinates with the excess hydroxyl groups on the surface of GO through hydrogen bonds. The strong nucleophilic anion Br − attacks the carbon atoms with low steric hindrance in PO, causing the C-O bond to break and open the ring to form intermediates. In steps III and IV, the strongly alkaline site in the DBU attacks CO2 molecules, causing a carbon-oxygen double bond in CO2 to break. The reaction of the obtained oxygen anion with the activated CO2 molecules leads to the generation of alkylcarbonate anion in step V. In the Ⅵ step, the catalytic process is completed by an intramolecular cycle to generate propylene carbonate and release the catalyst. 5 Conclusion In this paper, the supported ionic liquid catalyst GO-[DBU][Br] was designed and prepared by chemical grafting method for the first time, and its catalytic performance was investigated by batch and continuous methods respectively. GO-[DBU][Br] has good catalytic performance, the high PC yield and good stability can be obtained under suitable process parameters. Meanwhile, the optimal process parameters for continuous reaction were determined. The reusability of the catalyst was also investigated, and the yield was still 89.4% after five reuses. Meanwhile, a possible catalytic mechanism is proposed. Taken together, this indicates that GO-[DBU][Br] is a nontoxic, recyclable, environmentally friendly, efficient and reusable supported ionic liquid catalyst, which has great industrial application prospects. coredata.dc:description: Emissions of carbon dioxide can lead to the greenhouse effect, causing global warming and so on. conversion of carbon dioxide into high-value chemicals through catalysis, which is an effective method to successfully curb carbon emissions and prevent the greenhouse effect. Among them, CO2 chemical synthesis of cyclic carbonate is one of the important way. In this paper, a new type of supported ionic liquid catalyst (GO-[DBU][Br]) was synthesized by one-pot method. Subsequently, the GO-[DBU][Br] was applied to the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 in batch reaction and fixed bed continuous reaction, respectively. The stability of the catalyst was also explored, the GO-[DBU][Br] was easily separated and reused at least 5 times without significant loss of catalytic activity. The excellent catalytic performance comes from the synergistic effect of ionic liquid cations, halogenated anions, and a large number of oxygen-containing functional groups on the GO surface, a possible reaction mechanism was thus proposed. The study provides a safe, efficient, and industrial-scale continuous reaction system for CO2 utilization.
coredata.dc:title: A novel supported ionic liquid catalyst, GO-[DBU][Br] catalyzes cycloaddition of CO2 in a fixed-bed reactor
